sub_topic: Finding the magnitude and direction of a vector using trigonometry.
message_1: A ship sails due north at a speed of 30 km/hr. There is a current flowing towards the east at a speed of 10 km/hr. Find the magnitude and direction of the resultant velocity of the ship.
message_2:
To find the magnitude and direction of the resultant velocity of the ship, we can use the Pythagorean theorem and the tangent function to find the angle.

Let Vn be the velocity of the ship in the north direction (30 km/hr) and Ve be the velocity of the current in the east direction (10 km/hr).

1. Find the magnitude of the resultant velocity (Vr):

Vr = √(Vn^2 + Ve^2)
Vr = √(30^2 + 10^2)
Vr = √(900 + 100)
Vr = √1000
Vr ≈ 31.62 km/hr

2. Find the direction of the resultant velocity (θ):

tan(θ) = Ve / Vn
tan(θ) = 10 / 30
tan(θ) = 1/3

θ = arctan(1/3)
θ ≈ 18.43 degrees

The magnitude of the resultant velocity of the ship is approximately 31.62 km/hr, and the direction is approximately 18.43 degrees east of north.
